That's a great idea! Reaching out to Rachel about her business card is a perfect opportunity to inquire about any potential discounts or promotions she might be offering. Many yoga instructors and studios offer discounts for new students, package deals, or loyalty programs, so it's definitely worth asking.

Here are some suggestions on how you can approach the conversation:

1. **Be direct and polite**: Send Rachel a message or email asking if she offers any discounts for private sessions or group classes. You can say something like, "Hi Rachel, I'm interested in booking a private session with you and was wondering if you offer any discounts for new students or package deals?"
2. **Show your enthusiasm**: Let Rachel know that you're excited about her teaching style and the advice she gave you during the class. This can help build a connection and make her more likely to offer you a discount.
3. **Ask about package deals**: Inquire about package deals or discounts for multiple private sessions or group classes. This can be a cost-effective way to commit to a regular practice and show your commitment to your yoga journey.
4. **Inquire about referral programs**: If you're planning to refer friends or family members to Rachel's classes, ask if she has a referral program in place. This can be a win-win for both of you, as you'll get a discount and Rachel will get more students.

Here's an example message you could send:

"Hi Rachel, hope you're doing well! I really enjoyed your class on February 10th and appreciated the advice you gave me on poses for better sleep. I'm interested in booking a private session with you and was wondering if you offer any discounts for new students or package deals? I'm also curious if you have a referral program in place if I refer friends or family members to your classes. Looking forward to hearing back from you!"

Remember to be respectful of Rachel's time and business, and don't be pushy or aggressive in your request. Good luck, and I hope you're able to score a great deal!
